title: How to Make a Coin Purse

steps.headline: Get your supplies.
steps.description: You'll need two aluminum/plastic, standard rectangular juice pouches (think Capri-Sun, Kool-Aid Jammers, or similar products), some duct tape, stick-on velcro strips, and some scissors.

steps.headline: Prepare your juice pouch.
steps.description: Cut a long hole on the wide, flat bottom portion of the juice pouch to rinse it out. If your juice pouch is the type with a plastic drinking tube attached, you'll need to carefully remove it, but using this type of pouch is not recommended.

steps.headline: Cut your duct tape.
steps.description: Cut two 4" strips and one 6" strip of duct tape. Then cut each strip in half the long way. Rulers and exact-o knives help here.

steps.headline: Add tape trim.
steps.description: Taking your two pouches, add duct tape trim to both the top and bottom of one, and just the bottom of the other. You will use the shorter piece of tape for this. Place the first half of tape along the bottom edge of the juice pouch and then fold the other half over to cover the other side.

steps.headline: Fold the first pouch.
steps.description: Fold the bottom section of the double trimmed piece towards the back. This should be somewhere between folding it in half and folding it in thirds.

steps.headline: Nest the pouches.
steps.description: With the short fold on the table and the rest of the pouch standing up, take the second pouch and place it face-down with the top edge in the crease of the folded pouch. Use the last 4" strip of tape to cover that line and join the pouches together.

steps.headline: Tape up the sides.
steps.description: Fold down the rest of the second pouch so that the silver backs are touching. Then, use the 6" strips of tape to join together the long sides. Trim any extra tape at the ends.

steps.headline: Cut the openings.
steps.description: Trim the tape to the edges in order to open up the two pockets.

steps.headline: Add the velcro.
steps.description: Place one piece of velcro on the main body of the pouch where you want it to close. Place the other piece on top of the first and then fold down the flap. This will help you get the velcro in the right spot. Enjoy your new coin purse!

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: You can now use your coin purse!

steps.headline: Get your materials.
steps.description: You'll need fake leather or very thin real leather, a box cutter, strong glue, a button, tread and a strong needle, and scissors.

steps.headline: Make a pattern.
steps.description: You'll need a pattern for a large equilateral triangle. Search "equilateral triangle" on Google Images in order to get an image you can print out to use as a template.

steps.headline: Use your pattern to cut out your leather.
steps.description: Place the pattern on the wrong side of your leather, trace it, and cut it out very carefully with the box cutter.

steps.headline: Fold the leather.
steps.description: Fold the top point down to the center of the bottom edge and then fold one of the sides over to cover it. The unfolded side will become the opening flap.

steps.headline: Sew on the button.
steps.description: Mark the point that is create opposite of the flap. Sew the button onto the nice side of the leather, centered about 2 centimeter (0.8 in) from what would be the very tip of that point.

steps.headline: Create the pouch.
steps.description: Glue the two folded over pieces together to create the pouch. The button piece should end up on top so that the tip of the flap can be folded down to meet it.

steps.headline: Cut the hole for the button.
steps.description: Cut a slit in the flap tip to create a button hole.

steps.headline: Add finishing touches.
steps.description: You can add designs with gold paint or glue trim around the opening to hide the uneven edges if you want to.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: You can now use your coin purse!

steps.headline: Gather your fabric and sewing supplies.
steps.description: One square foot of fabric is sufficient, but you probably want extra.

steps.headline: With right sides together, fold the fabric in half.
steps.description: The folded edge will become the bottom of the purse. Stitch the side seams together, leaving a half-inch seam allowance.

steps.headline: Create your hemline.
steps.description: Turn the top of the purse over twice to create a half-inch hemline and iron it flat.

steps.headline: Place your drawstring.
steps.description: Place the string within the hem to use as a drawstring.

steps.headline: Stitch the hem.
steps.description: Stitch the hem together, leaving a small opening for the ends of the string.

steps.headline: Tie a knot in your string.
steps.description: Tie a knot at the end of each string to keep them from slipping back into the hemline.

steps.headline: Turn the bag right side out.
Pull the drawstrings to gather the opening of the bag.
steps.description: Tie the drawstring in a bow or double knot.

text: Juice Pouch Purse Get your supplies. You'll need two aluminum/plastic, standard rectangular juice pouches (think Capri-Sun, Kool-Aid Jammers, or similar products), some duct tape, stick-on velcro strips, and some scissors. Prepare your juice pouch. Cut a long hole on the wide, flat bottom portion of the juice pouch to rinse it out. If your juice pouch is the type with a plastic drinking tube attached, you'll need to carefully remove it, but using this type of pouch is not recommended. Cut your duct tape. Cut two 4" strips and one 6" strip of duct tape. Then cut each strip in half the long way. Rulers and exact-o knives help here. Add tape trim. Taking your two pouches, add duct tape trim to both the top and bottom of one, and just the bottom of the other. You will use the shorter piece of tape for this. Place the first half of tape along the bottom edge of the juice pouch and then fold the other half over to cover the other side. Fold the first pouch. Fold the bottom section of the double trimmed piece towards the back. This should be somewhere between folding it in half and folding it in thirds. Nest the pouches. With the short fold on the table and the rest of the pouch standing up, take the second pouch and place it face-down with the top edge in the crease of the folded pouch. Use the last 4" strip of tape to cover that line and join the pouches together. Tape up the sides. Fold down the rest of the second pouch so that the silver backs are touching. Then, use the 6" strips of tape to join together the long sides. Trim any extra tape at the ends. Cut the openings. Trim the tape to the edges in order to open up the two pockets. Add the velcro. Place one piece of velcro on the main body of the pouch where you want it to close. Place the other piece on top of the first and then fold down the flap. This will help you get the velcro in the right spot. Enjoy your new coin purse! Finished. You can now use your coin purse! Leather Triangle Purse Get your materials. You'll need fake leather or very thin real leather, a box cutter, strong glue, a button, tread and a strong needle, and scissors. Make a pattern. You'll need a pattern for a large equilateral triangle. Search "equilateral triangle" on Google Images in order to get an image you can print out to use as a template. Use your pattern to cut out your leather. Place the pattern on the wrong side of your leather, trace it, and cut it out very carefully with the box cutter. Fold the leather. Fold the top point down to the center of the bottom edge and then fold one of the sides over to cover it. The unfolded side will become the opening flap. Sew on the button. Mark the point that is create opposite of the flap. Sew the button onto the nice side of the leather, centered about 2 centimeter (0.8 in) from what would be the very tip of that point. Create the pouch. Glue the two folded over pieces together to create the pouch. The button piece should end up on top so that the tip of the flap can be folded down to meet it. Cut the hole for the button. Cut a slit in the flap tip to create a button hole. Add finishing touches. You can add designs with gold paint or glue trim around the opening to hide the uneven edges if you want to. Finished. You can now use your coin purse! Fabric Pouch Gather your fabric and sewing supplies. One square foot of fabric is sufficient, but you probably want extra. With right sides together, fold the fabric in half. The folded edge will become the bottom of the purse. Stitch the side seams together, leaving a half-inch seam allowance. Create your hemline. Turn the top of the purse over twice to create a half-inch hemline and iron it flat. Place your drawstring. Place the string within the hem to use as a drawstring. Stitch the hem. Stitch the hem together, leaving a small opening for the ends of the string. Tie a knot in your string. Tie a knot at the end of each string to keep them from slipping back into the hemline. Turn the bag right side out.  Pull the drawstrings to gather the opening of the bag. Tie the drawstring in a bow or double knot. Finished.
sentences: Juice Pouch Purse Get your supplies.
You'll need two aluminum/plastic, standard rectangular juice pouches (think Capri-Sun, Kool-Aid Jammers, or similar products), some duct tape, stick-on velcro strips, and some scissors.
Prepare your juice pouch.
Cut a long hole on the wide, flat bottom portion of the juice pouch to rinse it out.
If your juice pouch is the type with a plastic drinking tube attached, you'll need to carefully remove it, but using this type of pouch is not recommended.
Cut your duct tape.
Cut two 4" strips and one 6" strip of duct tape.
Then cut each strip in half the long way.
Rulers and exact-o knives help here.
Add tape trim.
Taking your two pouches, add duct tape trim to both the top and bottom of one, and just the bottom of the other.
You will use the shorter piece of tape for this.
Place the first half of tape along the bottom edge of the juice pouch and then fold the other half over to cover the other side.
Fold the first pouch.
Fold the bottom section of the double trimmed piece towards the back.
This should be somewhere between folding it in half and folding it in thirds.
Nest the pouches.
With the short fold on the table and the rest of the pouch standing up, take the second pouch and place it face-down with the top edge in the crease of the folded pouch.
Use the last 4" strip of tape to cover that line and join the pouches together.
Tape up the sides.
Fold down the rest of the second pouch so that the silver backs are touching.
Then, use the 6" strips of tape to join together the long sides.
Trim any extra tape at the ends.
Cut the openings.
Trim the tape to the edges in order to open up the two pockets.
Add the velcro.
Place one piece of velcro on the main body of the pouch where you want it to close.
Place the other piece on top of the first and then fold down the flap.
This will help you get the velcro in the right spot.
Enjoy your new coin purse!
Finished.
You can now use your coin purse!
Leather Triangle Purse Get your materials.
You'll need fake leather or very thin real leather, a box cutter, strong glue, a button, tread and a strong needle, and scissors.
Make a pattern.
You'll need a pattern for a large equilateral triangle.
Search "equilateral triangle" on Google Images in order to get an image you can print out to use as a template.
Use your pattern to cut out your leather.
Place the pattern on the wrong side of your leather, trace it, and cut it out very carefully with the box cutter.
Fold the leather.
Fold the top point down to the center of the bottom edge and then fold one of the sides over to cover it.
The unfolded side will become the opening flap.
Sew on the button.
Mark the point that is create opposite of the flap.
Sew the button onto the nice side of the leather, centered about 2 centimeter (0.8 in) from what would be the very tip of that point.
Create the pouch.
Glue the two folded over pieces together to create the pouch.
The button piece should end up on top so that the tip of the flap can be folded down to meet it.
Cut the hole for the button.
Cut a slit in the flap tip to create a button hole.
Add finishing touches.
You can add designs with gold paint or glue trim around the opening to hide the uneven edges if you want to.
Finished.
You can now use your coin purse!
Fabric Pouch Gather your fabric and sewing supplies.
One square foot of fabric is sufficient, but you probably want extra.
With right sides together, fold the fabric in half.
The folded edge will become the bottom of the purse.
Stitch the side seams together, leaving a half-inch seam allowance.
Create your hemline.
Turn the top of the purse over twice to create a half-inch hemline and iron it flat.
Place your drawstring.
Place the string within the hem to use as a drawstring.
Stitch the hem.
Stitch the hem together, leaving a small opening for the ends of the string.
Tie a knot in your string.
Tie a knot at the end of each string to keep them from slipping back into the hemline.
Turn the bag right side out.
Pull the drawstrings to gather the opening of the bag.
Tie the drawstring in a bow or double knot.
Finished.
